newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Samsung plan to relaunch Fokker - paper.
newsitem.headline: Samsung plan to relaunch Fokker - paper.

text.p: South Korea's Samsung Aerospace Industries has drawn up a business plan to takeover bankrupt Dutch planemaker Fokker that involves annual production of 42 aircraft by a company employing around 1,000 people, newspaper De Volkskrant said on Saturday.
The paper said Samsung would present the plan to Dutch Economics Affairs Minister Hans Wijers on Monday and that talks over Fokker's fate had entered a "crucial phase".
Quoting trade union sources, De Volkskrant said annual aircraft production would break down into 12 Fokker 50s, 15 Fokker 70s and 15 Fokker 100s.
No one was available at Fokker's receivers on Saturday.
Two weeks ago, the Dutch media reported that two senior executives from Samsung had arrived in the Netherlands to seal the acquisition of Fokker, declared bankrupt earlier this year.

But a spokeswoman for the receivers declined to comment at the time, saying there was nothing to add to the brief September 13 statement in which they said Samsung Aerospace had been given exclusive rights to examine Fokker's books with a view to a possible bid.
Media reports have since said there were plans for Samsung to take a 70 percent stake in Fokker, with engineering concern Stork and the Dutch state each taking 15 percent.
In July Stork acquired the profitable Fokker Aviation maintenance business which remained outside the bankruptcy.
Fokker was declared bankrupt in March after majority shareholder Daimler Benz Aerospace said it was no longer able to bear the Dutch company's huge losses.
